:"Lead sugar" redirects here.

'Lead(II) acetate' (Pb(CH 3COO) 2), also known as 'lead
acetate', 'lead diacetate', 'plumbous acetate', 'sugar of lead', 'lead sugar',
'salt of [[Saturn]]', and '[[Thomas Goulard|Goulard's]] powder', is a white
crystalline chemical compound with a sweetish taste. It is made by treating
lead(II) oxide with acetic acid. Like other lead compounds, it is toxic. Lead
acetate is soluble in water and glycerin. With water it forms the trihydrate,
Pb(CH 3COO) 2Â·3H 2O, a colorless or white
efflorescent monoclinic crystalline substance.

The substance is used as a reagent to make other lead compounds and as a
fixative for some dyes. In low concentrations, it is the principal active
ingredient in progressive types of hair coloring dyes. Lead(II) acetate is also
used as a mordant in textile printing and dyeing, as a drier in paints and
varnishes, and in preparing other lead compounds.
